Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Rigid and Flexible Linker Systems for Superior Immobilized Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Janet Bluemel of Texas A&M University to investigate homogeneous and immobilized molecular nickel catalysts in order to clarify the processes by which metal complexes decompose to form nanoparticles. Nickel(0) catalysts are immobilized on surfaces via phosphine linkers chosen from a broad range of mono-, di-, and tridentate ligands that incorporate flexible alkyl chains or rigid tetraphenylelement cores. Strategic ligand selection helps discriminate between dimerization on the surface and agglomeration as the crucial step in the eventual nanoparticle formation. The cyclotrimerization of phenylacetylene is used as a model reaction to study the selectivity and activity of the immobilized catalysts and to monitor potential nanoparticle formation. The dynamics of metal complex migration from one uncoordinated phosphine linker to the next on the surface is quantified using 31P T1 relaxation times and HRMAS NMR data. Metal complexes other than Ni(0) and different catalytic reactions are also investigated to probe the general applicability of the insights gained with the model catalytic system. Immobilized catalysts have the potential to improve industrial scale chemical processes and thus, this project may improve the environmental sustainability of large scale chemical synthesis by providing general methodologies for the preparation and use of non-precious metal catalysts with superior activities, selectivities, and lifetimes. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project receive interdisciplinary training and gain experience in advanced techniques for the characterization of amorphous materials.

The Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Janet Bluemel of the Texas A&M University to compare differences in homogeneous and immobilized catalysts. During homogeneous catalysis, nanoparticles can form from the metal catalyst resulting in a suspension of heterogeneous catalysts in solution. Starting from immobilized catalysts, the same process leads to nanoparticle formation on the surface. This uncontrollable scenario is undesirable because it is not predictable, not generally preventable, and may change the selectivity of the catalyst or shorten its lifetime, diminishing the recyclability of the catalyst. This research project investigates homogeneous and immobilized molecular nickel catalysts in order to clarify the processes associated with metal catalyst decomposition (e.g. decomposition on the surface or agglomeration in solution) to form nanoparticles. This project has the potential to improve the environmental sustainability of large scale chemical synthesis by providing general methodologies for the preparation and use of non-precious metal catalysts with superior activities, selectivities, and lifetimes. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project receive interdisciplinary training, collaborate internationally, and gain experience in advanced analytical techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catalysis plays a central role in the chemical sciences. About 80% of all products of daily use and chemicals have seen a catalyst at some point during their synthesis and manufacture. Therefore, improving catalysts means that processes can be made more energy efficient and benign towards the environment. The most important prerequisite for improving a catalyst is to better understand the interactions with its surroundings. For homogeneous catalysts this means interactions with other catalyst molecules or with the solvent. For heterogeneous catalysts, a solid component, most often the support for the catalyst, needs to be considered as well.

The main goal of the project was to make a positive impact on society by improving the catalysts needed for important products in the chemical industry and in daily life. The way towards this goal started in the project by investigating homogeneous catalysts that are tethered to a solid support, so-called immobilized catalysts, with respect to their behavior on surfaces and with substrates. Specifically, a deeper understanding of the various processes was sought that take place when homogeneous catalysts are immobilized on oxide surfaces and used in catalysis. Linkers and catalysts can, for example, be adsorbed on the surfaces and display unexpected dynamic effects. They can also undergo different reactions or changes in coordination. During the whole project, continued emphasis has been placed on the interactions of metal complexes and their phosphine linkers with silica, alumina, zirconiumphosphate, and various carbon surfaces. Hereby, monometallic systems of iron, nickel, and rhodium, and heterobimetallic systems of nickel/gold, and palladium/copper have been investigated regarding their structure, dynamic effects, interactions with the surfaces, and their catalytic activities. The main analytical tools were solid-state NMR spectroscopy and electron microscopy. New techniques adapted to solve the specific problems have been developed for studying all surface species. Applying the gained insights to different catalytic reactions led to immobilized catalysts with unprecedented activities, selectivites, and lifetimes.

Another key objective of this project was to learn more about the formation of nanoparticles during catalytic runs with immobilized catalysts. The nanoparticles could, in principle, form in solution and then deposit on the solid support. Alternatively, the nanoparticles could be generated at surface sites after the precursor complexes get into contact with the reactive surface. In this respect, both homogeneous and analogous immobilized catalysts have been studied. Since properly immobilized metal complexes do not leach into solution, some type of mobility of the metal complex fragments or the linkers on the surface was suspected. Several, previously unrecognized, different ways how metal complexes can move on surfaces could be identified and quantified.

In summary, the major goals of the project have been reached and in addition new discoveries have been made. The important and unprecedented new results have been published in top scientific, reviewed jounals as 19 full papers and 3 manuscripts have been submitted. Many more manuscripts are being composed and written up at the moment. The PI has given 33 lectures about the results in academia and industry, and the graduate students gave 51 oral and 71 poster presentations. Several poster prizes have been awarded to group members during this project. Furthermore, all graduate students on the project, as well as undergraduate students have been trained and mentored. Seven graduate students have finished their dissertations and they all obtained optimal jobs in industry and academia.


Last Modified: 10/14/2017
Modified by: Janet Bluemel
